hawaiian_text: 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ua 'ike au, he kanaka nui nō 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, a ua hele aku nei ma Ko'olau, a 'o wau he inoa nona." 'Ī mai lākou: "'A'ole, 'o 'oe nō, pela ko makou lohe, no laila, e make ana 'oe iā mākou, 'a'ole 'oe e ola." 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ho'i aku ho'i hā kākou i lalo e hakakā ai." A hiki lākou i lalo, e hao aku ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, pau loa i ka make, a koe aku ho'okahi kanaka, 'o ia ka i holo aku ā loa'a 'o 'Ama'u ma Waikīkī, 'ōlelo akula ia i ka make o lākou a pau loa, a koe ia i 'āha'ilono e lohe ai 'o 'Ama'u.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: "Call out to Nāmakaokapāo'o: 'I know, he is a great man, Nāmakaokapāo'o, and he has gone to Ko'olau, and your name is that.' They said: 'No, only you, like our words, now, you will kill us, you will not live.' Nāmakaokapāo'o said: 'Return, return, we will go down to fight.' They went down, and Pua-li'i is after Nāmakaokapāo'o, all dead, and you one man, that is the one who went to 'Ama'u in Waikīkī, spoke to the dead of them all, and you in the 'āha'ilono to speak of 'Ama'u."
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>  
"Call out to Nāmakaokapāo'o: 'I know, he is a great man, Nāmakaokapāo'o, and he has gone to Ko'olau, and your name is that.' They said: 'No, only you, like our words, now, you will kill us, you will not live.' Nāmakaokapāo'o said: 'Return, return, we will go down to fight.' They went down, and Pua-li'i is after Nāmakaokapāo'o, all dead, and you one man, that is the one who went to 'Ama'u in Waikīkī, spoke to the dead of them all, and you in the 'āha'ilono to speak of 'Ama'u."  
</translation>  

<commentary>  
**Paragraph 13:**  
• This passage reflects a critical turning point in the narrative, where Nāmakaokapāo'o confronts a group of people who accuse him of being a threat, symbolizing the tension between tradition and emerging power dynamics during the *Ai Kapu* era.  
– The dialogue highlights the protagonist’s defiance and the stakes of his actions, with "e make ana 'oe iā mākou" ("you will kill us") underscoring the fatalism of the time, where *Ai Kapu* restrictions often framed human actions as tied to divine will.  
– "Pua-li'i" (likely *Pua-lākou*, "the one who seizes" or "the one who takes") is a figure associated with the dead, possibly a guardian of the *moʻo* (spiritual realm) or a symbol of the *Ai Kapu* system’s enforcement.  
– "Ama'u" (a name possibly linked to *amaʻu*, "to be still" or "to rest") in *Waikīkī* may reference a sacred space or a metaphor for the afterlife, emphasizing the story’s connection to *moʻolele* (myths) and the spiritual journey of the protagonist.  
– The phrase "e hakakā ai" ("to fight") ties to the *kāne* (male) warrior ethos, contrasting with earlier depictions of Nāmakaokapāo'o as a child of "kanaka nui" (great man) and "pela ko makou lohe" (like our words), suggesting a shift from passive description to active confrontation.  
• Allegorically, the "one man" (*koe aku ho'okahi kanaka*) may represent the individual’s struggle against collective *kapu* (taboos), reflecting the collapse of the *Ai Kapu* system and the rise of new social orders.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I know. Nāmakaokapāo'o is a really big guy. He went to Ko'olau. I'm named after him." The soldiers said, "No, it's you. That's what we heard. So, we're going to kill you. You won't survive." Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "Well, let's go down and fight." When they got down, Nāmakaokapāo'o went to work and killed them all except one man, who ran off and reached 'Ama'u in Waikīkī. He told him about the how they were all killed except for one runner to go and tell 'Ama'u about it.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
